task.title: Configure the Origin
task.shortdesc: The origin represents the source data for the pipeline. When you configure the origin, you define how to connect to the origin system, the type of data to be processed, and other origin-specific properties.

context.p: To process data in a static file, we'll use the Directory origin. If we wanted to tail an active file, we would use the File Tail origin.

step.cmd: To add the stage to the canvas, in the Stage list, click the Directory origin. Or, from the Pipeline Creation Help Bar, click Select Origin Directory .
step.info: Do I need a screenshot here to show the two options? The origin displays in the canvas and the Properties panel displays the stage properties.

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, click the Files tab and configure the following properties - use defaults for all other properties:

row.entry:
Directory where you saved the source file.
For example: /myFiles/Tutorial.

The Directory origin processes only the files in the directory that match the file name pattern.
The tutorial sample file name is nyc_taxi_data.csv. If the file is the only file in the directory, you can use the asterisk wild card (*) or something similarly generic, like *.csv.
If you had other .csv files in the directory, you might be more specific, like this: nyc_taxi*.csv.
Or if you knew that you'd be processing files from other cities, you might use *taxi*.csv.

When processing a set of files with the same file name pattern, Directory normally starts with the first file and continues in naturally ascending order, e.g. nyc_taxi_data.csv, then nyc_taxi_data2.csv, etc.
If you wanted to skip some files, you would enter the file to start with. In this case, we're processing a single file, so let's leave this empty.

step.cmd: For delimited data, additional properties are available, so click the Delimited tab.
The sample data includes a header row, so set the Header Line property to With Header Line.
